title: Quiz 3: Medicine FQE June 2023
description: Final Qualifying Examination from June 2023 covering Clinical Medicine and Surgery.

questions.question: A 27-year-old patient previously treated for brucellosis presents with dull headache and undulating fever. Repeat Brucella Antigen Test reveals elevated titres for BA and BM. Which organism is implicated in this recurrent chronic infection?
questions.explanation: Brucella melitensis (associated with goats/sheep) is the most virulent species and is most commonly associated with severe, chronic, and relapsing brucellosis (Undulating/Malta Fever).
questions.hint: The most virulent species, associated with goats and sheep.

questions.question: A 30-year-old lady presents with headache and joint pains while on treatment for peptic ulcer disease. Stool SAT test reveals Salmonella antigens. Which host factor increased her susceptibility?

options.text: During treatment of peptic ulcer disease

questions.explanation: Gastric acid is a defense against Salmonella. PUD treatment (antacids/PPIs) reduces acidity (hypochlorhydria), lowering the infectious dose required for infection.
questions.hint: Think about the stomach's natural barrier against bacteria.

questions.question: A patient diagnosed with Cholera was administered Loperamide before referral. What is the anticipated risk of this management?
questions.explanation: Loperamide stops motility, preventing the flushing out of cholera toxins. This leads to fluid sequestration in the bowel, toxic megacolon, and paralytic ileus.
questions.hint: Stopping the flow keeps the toxin inside.

questions.question: Patients present with vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pains 24 hours after a party. Stool analysis reveals motile Clostridium botulinum bacteria. How is this condition classified?
questions.explanation: While Botulism is often an intoxication, the presence of the *bacteria* in stool suggests ingestion of the organism itself (Infection) rather than just pre-formed toxin.
questions.hint: Ingesting the organism vs ingesting the toxin.

questions.question: A patient has recurrent episodes of intestinal amoebiasis. What is the likely cause of the relapse?

options.text: Administration of metronidazole alone at the symptomatic phase
Administration of Iodoquinol at the symptomatic phase
Administration of metronidazole and Diloxanide furoate

questions.explanation: Metronidazole treats invasive trophozoites but not the cysts in the lumen. A luminal amoebicide (like Diloxanide) is required to eradicate cysts and prevent relapse.

questions.question: Which antibiotic is recommended for Anthrax post-exposure prophylaxis?
questions.explanation: Doxycycline (or Ciprofloxacin) is the standard PEP for Anthrax exposure.
questions.hint: A tetracycline often used for zoonotic infections.

questions.question: What is the priority treatment in cholera patients?
questions.explanation: Death in cholera is due to dehydration. Rapid rehydration is the single most critical intervention.

questions.question: A 14-year-old with cough and abdominal pain expectorates 2 worms. Which helminth is likely implicated?
questions.explanation: Ascaris larvae migrate through the lungs (causing cough) and adults can migrate up the esophagus to be coughed/vomited out.
questions.hint: Large roundworm known for lung migration.

questions.question: Which parasitic antigen guides the choice of Malaria RDT kit for Plasmodium falciparum?
questions.explanation: HRP2 is the specific antigen produced by Plasmodium falciparum used in RDTs.

questions.question: Which drug would you recommend for malaria chemoprophylaxis for tourists visiting an endemic zone?
questions.explanation: Mefloquine is a standard prophylactic. Artesunate and Quinine are for treatment.

questions.question: A patient suspected of viral Hemorrhagic fever will present with?

options.text: Fever and headache in non-endemic zones
Fever and haemorrhage in endemic zones
Fever plus presence of HF antigens in bloody by ELISA

questions.explanation: The clinical case definition requires Fever + Bleeding + Endemic area history.

questions.question: The sequelae of the rabies virus infection in humans is attributed to?
questions.explanation: Hydrophobia (fear of water) due to pharyngeal spasms is the pathognomonic feature of Rabies.

questions.question: Varicella zoster virus infection has which of the following characteristic?

options.text: Infection occurs once in a lifetime only
Fever is the only suspicious indicator

questions.explanation: There is a vaccine for Chickenpox (Varicella). Infection can recur as Shingles.

questions.question: A patient with pneumonia has patchy opacities on CXR. What is the classification?
questions.explanation: Bronchopneumonia is characterized radiologically by patchy, diffuse opacities.

questions.question: The TB-LAM test detects mycobacterium TB antigens in which specimen?
questions.explanation: TB-LAM detects Lipoarabinomannan antigen in Urine.

questions.question: A 19-year-old student presents with wheezing, cough, and dyspnea increasing in the cold season. What is the emergency management?
questions.explanation: In acute asthma exacerbation, nebulized Salbutamol (Ventolin) is the first-line emergency treatment.

questions.question: The unique radiological feature of Pneumocystis Jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is:
questions.explanation: Bilateral diffuse ground-glass opacities are characteristic of PCP.

questions.question: Which of the following is a non-modifiable risk for asthma?
questions.explanation: Atopy (genetic tendency for allergies) is intrinsic and non-modifiable.

questions.question: Which of the following is a long term complication of acute rheumatic fever?
questions.explanation: Sydenham's Chorea is a late-onset manifestation. The others are acute phase signs.
questions.hint: A neurological movement disorder appearing late.

questions.question: The most affected valve (>90%) in rheumatic carditis is?
questions.explanation: The Mitral valve is the most commonly affected valve in Rheumatic Heart Disease.
questions.hint: The valve on the left side between atrium and ventricle.

questions.question: Which cardiomyopathy is a sequelae of cardiac infection (myocarditis)?
questions.explanation: Viral myocarditis often leads to Dilated Cardiomyopathy.
questions.hint: The heart walls stretch and thin out.

questions.question: A Heart Failure patient is dyspneic at rest. What is the NYHA class?
questions.explanation: NYHA Class IV is defined as symptoms present at rest.

questions.question: In infective endocarditis, the symptomatic clinical stage is attributed to?
questions.explanation: Systemic symptoms (fever, malaise) are driven by the inflammatory cytokine response.

questions.question: A 47-year-old man admitted with BP of 183/105mmHg and impeding stroke is categorized as?
questions.explanation: High BP with acute end-organ damage (impeding stroke) is a Hypertensive Emergency.

questions.question: The DASH recommendation on alcohol intake for hypertension is?

options.text: Immediate cessation of alcohol in hypertension
Intake of up to 16 units per week in women
Intake of up to 30 units per week in men

questions.explanation: While moderation is often preached, the best medical advice for managing hypertension via DASH principles prioritizes minimization/cessation.
questions.hint: Less is better, none is best.

questions.question: Which anti-hypertensive is recommended in patients with gouty arthritis?
questions.explanation: Losartan (ARB) has a uricosuric effect, helping lower uric acid.
questions.hint: An ARB that lowers uric acid.

questions.question: Which of the following is a risk factor for bradyarrhythmias?
questions.explanation: Propranolol is a beta-blocker that slows the heart rate.
questions.hint: A drug that blocks sympathetic drive.

questions.question: A man has massive oedema and proteinuria 4+. The oedema is triggered by?
questions.explanation: In Nephrotic Syndrome, massive protein loss leads to low serum albumin (Hypoalbuminemia), reducing oncotic pressure and causing edema.
questions.hint: Low protein in blood due to loss in urine.

questions.question: What is the stage of kidney injury in a patient with GFR of 60-89?
questions.explanation: Stage 2 CKD is GFR 60-89 ml/min.

questions.question: Which of the following is an intrinsic precipitant of kidney injury?
questions.explanation: Vasculitis affects the kidney vessels directly (Intrinsic). Others are Pre-renal or Post-renal.

questions.question: In peritoneal dialysis, which of the following is the primary access?
questions.explanation: Peritoneal dialysis uses a catheter inserted into the abdomen.

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with post hepatic portal hypertension?
questions.explanation: Hepatic vein thrombosis (Budd-Chiari) occurs after the liver, blocking outflow.
questions.hint: Blockage in the veins leaving the liver.

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with low SAAG (Serum Ascites Albumin Gradient)?
questions.explanation: Low SAAG (<1.1) indicates non-portal hypertension causes like Nephrotic Syndrome or TB.

questions.question: A patient presents with epigastric burning pain relieved by food. H. Pylori is positive. What is the impression?
questions.explanation: 'Hunger pain' relieved by food is classic for Duodenal Ulcer.

questions.question: A patient from a village presents with severe headache, photophobia, and neck stiffness. LP is positive. Which organism is implicated?
questions.explanation: Neisseria meningitidis is the classic cause of epidemic meningitis.

questions.question: Identify the type of peripheral blood film results in folate deficiency anaemia?
questions.explanation: Megaloblastic anemia (Folate/B12 deficiency) causes Macrocytic Normochromic cells.

questions.question: A 15-year-old with sickle cell anaemia presents with fever and sudden drop of Hb from 6g/dl to 3g/dl. Identify the condition?
questions.explanation: A sudden severe drop in Hb with fever suggests Aplastic Crisis (often Parvovirus B19).

questions.question: Which of the following is an anticipated feature of leukemia in complete blood count (CBC)?
questions.explanation: Leukemia typically presents with high WBC counts (Leukocytosis), mostly immature cells.

questions.question: Which one of the following is a WHO stage 3 condition in HIV?
questions.explanation: Pulmonary TB is Stage 3. Extra-pulmonary is Stage 4.

questions.question: Couple presents for HIV test. Both partners test positive. How do you classify the couple?
questions.explanation: Concordant means they match. Concordant Positive means both are positive.

questions.question: Manage a 23-year-old breastfeeding mother diagnosed with TB. Select the correct interventions:

options.text: Initiate standard anti-TB therapy (2RHZE/4RH) for mother
Advise mother to STOP breastfeeding immediately
Encourage continued breastfeeding with infection prevention (mask)
Administer Isoniazid Preventive Therapy (IPT) to the infant

questions.explanation: Treat mother, continue breastfeeding, protect baby with IPT. Separation is not recommended.
questions.hint: Breastfeeding is safe with precautions and baby prophylaxis.

questions.question: A female student presents with an ulcer on the labia majora. Select potential differential diagnoses:
questions.explanation: Common causes of genital ulcers include Syphilis, Herpes, Chancroid, and LGV. Candida causes discharge/itch, rarely ulcers.

questions.question: A patient presents with congenital hypopigmented lesions and new pruritus. Select differential diagnoses for the lesions:
questions.explanation: DDx for hypopigmentation includes congenital causes (Albinism, Piebaldism) and acquired/fungal (Pityriasis, Vitiligo).

questions.question: Match the Imaging Technique to its Indication:
questions.explanation: Xray=Bone/Air, USS=Fluid/Fetus, CT=Brain/Bone detail, MRI=Soft tissue/Nerves, Fluoroscopy=Live motion.
questions.hint: Match the tool to the tissue type.

questions.question: Manage a patient with Otitis Externa (Ear pain, itchiness, discharge). Select correct steps:
questions.explanation: Key is cleaning (toilet), topical treatment, and keeping it dry. Irrigation is contraindicated if tympanic membrane status is unknown or in active infection.

questions.question: A patient presents with bizarre behavior, hallucinations, and mania. Select differential diagnoses:
questions.explanation: Psychiatric causes (Bipolar, Schizophrenia) and Medical causes (Drugs, Malaria, Thyroid) can present with mania/psychosis.

questions.question: Classify the complications of Diabetes Mellitus:

richContent.content:
CategoryDescription
MicrovascularSmall vessel damage (Eyes, Kidneys, Nerves)
MacrovascularLarge vessel damage (Heart, Brain, Legs)

questions.explanation: Micro = Eyes/Kidneys/Nerves. Macro = Heart/Brain/Peripheral Arteries.

questions.question: A 90-year-old presents with memory loss, tremors, and unsteady gait. Select differential diagnoses:
questions.explanation: Neurodegenerative diseases causing dementia and motor symptoms.
questions.hint: Causes of dementia and movement disorders.

questions.question: Case: 85-year-old with morning stiffness, redness, and swelling of knee/elbow. No trauma. Select appropriate Management steps:

richContent.content:
Case Study

Patient: 85-year-old.
Symptoms: Morning stiffness, Red/Swollen joints (Knee/Elbow).
History: No trauma.

DDx: RA, Gout, Septic Arthritis.

options.text: Blood tests (ESR, CRP, Uric Acid, RF)

questions.explanation: Workup involves confirming diagnosis (Aspiration/Labs/Xray) and managing pain/inflammation based on findings (Gout vs RA).
